et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}exclusion-, exclusio{/it}, from {it}excludere{/it}
shortdef: the act or an instance of excluding

dt: {bc}a principle in physics: no two particles (such as electrons) in an atom or molecule can have the same set of quantum numbers

shortdef: a principle in physics: no two particles (such as electrons) in an atom or molecule can have the same set of quantum numbers —called also Pauli exclusion principle

dt: {bc}the act of {d_link|excluding|exclude} oneself from some activity

dt.t: … the difficulty in determining that the {wi}self-exclusion{/wi} is truly voluntary where it is apparent that attempts to integrate would be rebuffed.

dt: {bc}a formal process by which one may opt to be barred from access to legal gambling activities in a specified area or venue

dt.t: [Tony] Santo said … they will offer people with gambling addictions the option of {ldquo}voluntary {wi}self-exclusion{/wi}{rdquo} from the casino, which staff will then enforce.
A problem gambler who signs up for the {wi}self-exclusion{/wi} list won't be allowed to enter any of Indiana's casinos.

shortdef: the act of excluding oneself from some activity; specifically : a formal process by which one may opt to be barred from access to legal gambling activities in a specified area or venue —often used before another noun

dt: {bc}in a way that excluded (someone or something)

dt.t: He spent all his time with colleagues {it}to the exclusion of{/it} his own family.

shortdef: in a way that excluded (someone or something)
